3F02C2B300A44A538C6C77F51D0FAEF4.description:
narrate, describe, and explain with increasing specificity and detail to fulfill
content area writing needs as more English is acquired.

5C928AD85B7A4AE78351BB0D78DEB860.description: using correct verbs, tenses, and pronouns/antecedents;

1B662124190C409EB5AF1582A13D58CE.description:
employ increasingly complex grammatical structures in content area writing
commensurate with grade-level expectations, such as:

DBC0F7F3F6304C7381ADD809790FB4EF.description:
spell familiar English words with increasing accuracy, and employ English
spelling patterns and rules with increasing accuracy as more English is acquired;

9BDA7892A5F1464EB9CDE1CEAB2758F0.description:
write using newly acquired basic vocabulary and content-based grade-level
vocabulary;

4A3A50F26DB94B24892982DB8BBC329B.description:
learn relationships between sounds and letters of the English language to
represent sounds when writing in English;

7893CB567F4C4AFF953FB243D9BD4FA1.description:
The ELL writes in a variety of
forms with increasing accuracy to effectively address a specific purpose and audience in
all content areas. ELLs may be at the beginning, intermediate, advanced, or advanced
high stage of English language acquisition in writing. In order for the ELL to meet gradelevel
learning expectations across foundation and enrichment curriculum, all instruction
delivered in English must be linguistically accommodated (communicated, sequenced,
and scaffolded) commensurate with the student's level of English language proficiency.
For Kindergarten and Grade 1, certain of these student expectations do not apply until the
student has reached the stage of generating original written text using a standard writing
system.

40115B18E4C148D585D39C9BF1C06AB7.description:
demonstrate English comprehension and expand reading skills by employing
analytical skills such as evaluating written information and performing critical
analyses commensurate with content area and grade-level needs.

7409CD6A0485465BBF33022F9CDE1651.description:
demonstrate English comprehension and expand reading skills by employing
inferential skills such as predicting, making connections between ideas, drawing
inferences and conclusions from text and graphic sources, and finding supporting
text evidence commensurate with content area needs;

064ADC884511477E8D2E6DE736C15B10.description:
demonstrate English comprehension and expand reading skills by employing
basic reading skills such as demonstrating understanding of supporting ideas and
details in text and graphic sources, summarizing text, and distinguishing main
ideas from details commensurate with content area needs;

97873FAA581F49E6A6777A5705798B62.description: read silently with increasing ease and comprehension for longer periods;

AFF0544AC3E5474B9241BDE03C82DEC4.description:
use visual and contextual support and support from peers and teachers to read
grade-appropriate content area text, enhance and confirm understanding, and
develop vocabulary, grasp of language structures, and background knowledge
needed to comprehend increasingly challenging language;

A344C77EF64049BFB044DC0EDD2D3239.description:
read linguistically accommodated content area material with a decreasing
need for linguistic accommodations as more English is learned;

52B0F56E7CA34D26A46D17B2103B510A.description:
recognize directionality of English reading such as left to right and top to
bottom;

D2342D0EAE4D40D2BB1B31B0492E4577.description:
READING. The ELL reads a variety of
texts for a variety of purposes with an increasing level of comprehension in all content
areas. ELLs may be at the beginning, intermediate, advanced, or advanced high stage of
English language acquisition in reading. In order for the ELL to meet grade-level learning
expectations across the foundation and enrichment curriculum, all instruction delivered in
English must be linguistically accommodated (communicated, sequenced, and
scaffolded) commensurate with the student's level of English language proficiency. For
Kindergarten and Grade 1, certain of these student expectations apply to text read aloud
for students not yet at the stage of decoding written text.

41F701C62D244D4B9E6AD6A52F1AA89C.description:
respond orally to information presented in a wide variety of print, electronic,
audio, and visual media to build and reinforce concept and language attainment.

1D15D511C4034C8FAD00601E8D9E8D26.description: adapt spoken language appropriately for formal and informal purposes;

880B97AFE068495D89932BD53E6CE2F4.description:
narrate, describe, and explain with increasing specificity and detail as more
English is acquired;

2CFC5D433F7D4FF3B9E3A9F8CE0AFD4E.description:
ask and give information ranging from using a very limited bank of highfrequency,
high-need, concrete vocabulary, including key words and expressions
needed for basic communication in academic and social contexts, to using abstract
and content-based vocabulary during extended speaking assignments;

18DAE7CF1CA048939DA5B44188D38F57.description: share information in cooperative learning interactions;

D56B0DC34513438E8E62DB40A9A12810.description:
speak using grade-level content area vocabulary in context to internalize new
English words and build academic language proficiency;

F9F2C9F955904CF8A7D06C95067A9974.description:
expand and internalize initial English vocabulary by learning and using high frequency
English words necessary for identifying and describing people, places,
and objects, by retelling simple stories and basic information represented or
supported by pictures, and by learning and using routine language needed for
classroom communication;

9A9A47A13D104EA1BBC1907F1B04D2A8.description:
SPEAKING. The ELL speaks in a variety
of modes for a variety of purposes with an awareness of different language registers
(formal/informal) using vocabulary with increasing fluency and accuracy in language arts
and all content areas. ELLs may be at the beginning, intermediate, advanced, or advanced
high stage of English language acquisition in speaking. In order for the ELL to meet
grade-level learning expectations across the foundation and enrichment curriculum, all
instruction delivered in English must be linguistically accommodated (communicated,
sequenced, and scaffolded) commensurate with the student's level of English language
proficiency

21D62F71F1EE47718FAD072D3C44758E.description:
demonstrate listening comprehension of increasingly complex spoken English
by following directions, retelling or summarizing spoken messages, responding to 
questions and requests, collaborating with peers, and taking notes commensurate
with content and grade-level needs.

78EC9CDCDF5347E989F815D57E7173A5.description:
understand implicit ideas and information in increasingly complex spoken
language commensurate with grade-level learning expectations

5A17B5975E86483E9BF111BF25F1F132.description:
use visual, contextual, and linguistic support to enhance and confirm
understanding of increasingly complex and elaborated spoken language;

B88394145D48440C94696BA5F2AA4843.description:
monitor understanding of spoken language during classroom instruction and
interactions and seek clarification as needed;

7ED9801892B04072AF87379A085F8505.description:
learn new language structures, expressions, and basic and academic
vocabulary heard during classroom instruction and interactions;

2784C306DC3A46ACA4C271C2CEE6BA4B.description:
recognize elements of the English sound system in newly acquired
vocabulary such as long and short vowels, silent letters, and consonant clusters;

CAC6FFF189614CE098B8A9ABDA8E0590.description: distinguish sounds and intonation patterns of English with increasing ease;

39B759218A024578AC440433D0FA506E.description:
LISTENING. The ELL listens to a variety
of speakers including teachers, peers, and electronic media to gain an increasing level of
comprehension of newly acquired language in all content areas. ELLs may be at the
beginning, intermediate, advanced, or advanced high stage of English language
acquisition in listening. In order for the ELL to meet grade-level learning expectations
across the foundation and enrichment curriculum, all instruction delivered in English
must be linguistically accommodated (communicated, sequenced, and scaffolded)
commensurate with the student's level of English language proficiency.

3E632EBF0DF049F9A3E112BDE713BFC8.description:
develop and expand repertoire of learning strategies such as reasoning
inductively or deductively, looking for patterns in language, and analyzing
sayings and expressions commensurate with grade-level learning expectations.

2E6770A81F054D01BDD9CB8AC062601E.description: use accessible language and learn new and essential language in the process;

F08A65426E1548258DF51AB1A9FF68F0.description:
monitor oral and written language production and employ self-corrective
techniques or other resources;

3B74F5B769DA4416BC147FF4AE377FB6.description: use prior knowledge and experiences to understand meanings in English;

51E255EBA7DE4E82AEF266AF260C8A3A.description:
S.L.A. LEARNING STRATEGIES. The ELL uses
language learning strategies to develop an awareness of his or her own learning processes
in all content areas. In order for the ELL to meet grade-level learning expectations across
the foundation and enrichment curriculum, all instruction delivered in English must be
linguistically accommodated (communicated, sequenced, and scaffolded) commensurate
with the student's level of English language proficiency.
